title: Before the Sphere, There Was the Cube
subheader: How a DKIT hallway chat and weekend calls became Republic of Fun Ltd.
content:
The origin of Republic of Fun Ltd. is a DKIT hallway story with weekend momentum.

During a Masters programme at DKIT, Michael (Moykul) OConghaile was a lecturer; Natalia di Simone and Marcos Ventura were students who kept showing up early, staying late, and smiling at problems that should have been terrifying. On the last day of the course, Natalia and Marcos asked Michael how to set up a game studio. Michael listened, nodded, andclassic Michaelmade a bigger offer: lets start one together.

Two things clicked immediately:

  • Natalia would be the codercalm, precise, allergic to unsolved bugs.

From there a ritual formed: weekly meetups, mostly Discord calls on Saturday and Sunday mornings, with occasional in-person sprints when calendars align. The game idea and the company name (Republic of Fun Ltd.) were Michaels suggestions. The original mission was small and stubborn in the best way: make games and have fun while doing it. Build something, test it, laugh, fix it, repeat.

Very early, a motto surfaced and stuck: before the sphere, there was the cube. Cubes dont coast; they commit. That attitude shaped the studios first experiments and set the tone for everything that followedjoyful, clever, and made to be played with friends.

Meet the trio:

  • Marcos (visuals): anime/manga nerd with suspicious amounts of espresso.
  • Natalia (coding): cat-powered, code-powered, probably refactoring while you read this.
  • Michael (business/inventions): conjurer of light, magic, and features the team swore werent possible yesterday.

Republic of Fun isnt a sloganits a filter. If an idea isnt joyful, clever, and playable with friends, it waits outside. The cube passed that test on day one, and its been politely shoving everything else off the mat ever since.

Thanks for being here at the start. More dev logs, character reveals, and glorious ring-outs coming soon. Stay cubic.

title: The Cube Heroes: How We Developed the First Four Characters
content:
SumoQubes needed fighters you could recognise by silhouette, sound, and one reckless decision. We aimed for comedy-first characters that still make tactical sense. Meet the OG four:

1) Shorty McBravado The Overconfident Shorty

A tiny cube with a stadium-sized ego. Struts like a champion, talks like a commentator, exits like a lawn dart.

  • Signature bit: the mythic Thunderquake Toss (which almost never works).
  • Excuses on defeat: slippery floors, unfair wind, opponent cheated. Secret late-night lessons hell never admit to.
  • Playstyle: explosive lunges, high-risk edge shoves, momentum-or-bust.

2) Blondo Slamson The Vain Himbo

Gold-tinted glory cube who believes victory is a mirror you can flex at. Checks reflections in anything shiny (including opponents). Gets distracted mid-bout admiring his own angles.

  • Catchphrase: Victory is temporary, but beauty is forever!
  • Playstyle: swagger stacksdominates when focused, faceplants when vanity interrupts.

3) Big Boppo The Chill Giant

Largest cube in the dojo, softest heart on the mat. Moves slow, speaks slower, snacks constantly. Offers ancient wisdom thats always food-based: Sumo is like souplet it simmer. When he plants his feet, nobody moves him.

  • Playstyle: anchor tank, serene counters, immovable center of gravity.

4) Zippy Zoomo The Hyperactive Rookie

A caffeinated blur with a PhD in overthinking. Trains nonstop, invents wild advanced sumo physics, and challenges everyone to rematches. Burns half his stamina before the bell.

  • Playstyle: speed spam, bait-and-zoom, hilarious self-timeouts.

Design pillars we stuck to

  • Readable silhouettes (even at a glance).
  • One mechanical joke per heroeasy to learn, devilish to master.
  • Joy-first tuningif its funny and fair, it ships.

title: GamerFest Dublin: Our First Alpha On the Floor
subheader: From first official showcase to a feedback goldmine
content:
GamerFest Dublin was Republic of Fun Ltd.s first official event with a playable prototypeand it felt like launching a paper airplane that actually kept flying.

We met loads of lovely peopleother indie devs and guests from ages 4 to 60who stress-tested SumoQubes nonstop. The vibe was pure party mode, powered by excellent coffee courtesy of Michael.

  • Milestone unlocked: first public alpha as a company.
  • Feedback goldmine: suggestions on controls, readability, and micro-UX we implemented later.
  • Mini survey, big insights: actionable data on difficulty and favourite modes.
  • Playtesting both ways: we also tested many wonderful games from fellow indies.
  • Official game tester debut: Valentino (Michaels middle son) took the role very seriously.
  • New look: fresh banner and team t-shirts on display.

Verdict: a great, amazing experience. Dublin, well be back with an even better build.

title: Make It AR  First Tests + PRISM Demo
subheader: Tabletop ring-outs and very curious onlookers
content:
Because Michael cant stop inventing, we started testing an AR version of SumoQubes: your table becomes the ring, your lamp is an obstacle, and your cat is a spectator with zero chill. At PRISM, Michael demoed the prototypeanchors stable, shadows grounded, cube fighters yeeting between coffee mugs. People leaned in. A lot.

What works already: quick plane detection and ring placement; occlusion and soft shadows that sell the theyre really here moment; touch-drag controls mapped to pushes and pivots.

What were fixing: multiplayer sync, auto-recenter when someone bumps the table IRL, and UI hints that dont look taped to your retina.

A small closed AR test is on the horizonbring a big table and a bigger smile.

title: PlayThis IGF  An Indie Party Were Building
subheader: A cozy, high-signal showcase for great games and friendly people
content:
Were organising PlayThis IGF: a curated indie day built around three verbsPlay, Talk, Connect. Expect hands-on demos, dev-to-dev chats, lightning talks, and a community corner for student projects and spicy experiments. Smooth ticketing via Eventbrite and short, useful newsletter updates keep the vibe focused on games, not logistics.

For developers: bring a playable slice, a tight pitch, and your best five minuteswell handle the flow, signage, and power.

For players: arrive curious, try everything, and tell creators what delighted you (and what confused you, politely). If you love joyful, clever games made for friends, this is your room.

Submissions, tickets, and collaborator news are comingwatch this space.
